FacilityStr1: Road F NW and 1st Road NW

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP)  Title 40 CFR §68
Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP Program.
This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Valley Ag has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP related activities. 
1.1 Valley Ag, Risk Management Program
This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Valley Ag has developed their unified RMP Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities:
Ammonia Storage - Anhydrous Ammonia - 130,000 lbs.
Our RMP Program promotes overall plant, worker, public, and environmental safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.
Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
Prepared a unified program based on the RMP obligations as well
Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)
The RMP Program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.
1.2 Process Description
Facility Overview
Valley Agronomics operates an ammonia fertilizer storage and retail l

ocation in Waterville, WA. The ammonia storage process operates as follows. Ammonia is supplied by a vendor into the ammonia storage tank. From there it is stored until a sale is made, at which time a Valley Agronomics employee transfers ammonia from the storage tank into a smaller trailer-mounted nurse tank. The nurse tanks are towed by trucks off-site for the fertilizer application.
Facility Location
Valley Agronomics is located at Road F NW and 1st Road NW, Waterville, WA 98858. The latitude and longitude of the ammonia storage tank is 47.623166, -119.878247. The facility is located approximately 0.7 miles north of U.S. Route 2 in a rural area.
A review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Valley Agronomics had a 1-2% chance of experiencing potentially minor-damage due to ground shaking in 2018.
The USGS 2023 50-State Long-term National Seismic Hazard Model revealed that Valley Agronomics has a 75-95% chance of slight (or greater) damaging earthquake shaking in 100 years.
Safety Systems
Pressure Relief Valves
Pressure relief valves are installed on the ammonia storage vessel and the ammonia pump is configured with a bypass valve. The relief valves have a set pressure of  250 psig and discharge to the atmosphere. Refer to the Relief System Design and Design Basis documentation for more information.
Analog Gauges
Various analog gauges are installed on the ammonia storage. The gauges provide the ability for operators to monitor vessel pressure and fill percentage.
Excess Flow / Emergency Shutoff Valves
The ammonia storage tank is configured with three (3) internal jet bleed valves which serve as emergency shutoff valves and excess flow valves. Ball valves are installed downstream of each internal jet bleed valve and are used for normal shutoff. The cables are connected to each jet bleed valve handle so that the valves can be closed remot

ely during an emergency.
Emergency Water Trough
A 200 gallon water trough is available near the ammonia storage tank during times of the year when ammonia transfers will take place.
Pump Controls
The pump engine is equipped with normal start/stop controls adjacent to the pump.
Signage
Piping and equipment associated with the ammonia system are clearly marked with tags, labels, and signs.
Process Classification
The ammonia system at Valley Agronomics consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the ammonia process at Valley Agronomics is treated as a single process.
1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
1.3.1 General 
We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.
Valley Ag has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia fertilizer process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 
1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia
The ammonia fertilizer process at the Valley Ag facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.
Our field personnel monitor the ammonia fertilizer process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia.
1.4 Five Year Accident History
Valley Ag has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.
1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan
Valley Ags emergency action and response program has been developed to

satisfy the following requirements:
U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administrations (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans  Title 29 CFR §1910.38
USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements]  Title 40 CFR §68.90-96
Federal Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER)  Title 29 CFR §1910.120(q)
Strategically, Valley Ag has chosen to be a non-responding stationary source. Our employees will not respond to accidental releases of ammonia. In lieu of responding to accidental releases, Valley Ag is implementing the following protocols:
The facility is included in the community emergency response plan developed under Title 42 USC §11003.
Appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.
Annual emergency response coordination activities are performed (Section 1.5.1).
Annual notification exercises are performed (Section 1.5.2).
1.5.1 Emergency Response Coordination Activities
The purpose of emergency response coordination activities is to coordinate response needs with local emergency planning and response organizations. The intent is for local response organizations to be made aware of the regulated substances (anhydrous ammonia) at Valley Ag, the quantities, the risks presented by the covered processes, and the resources and capabilities at our facility to respond to an accidental release of a regulated substance. The emergency response coordination activities will consist of the following:
Coordinations will be completed at least annually. Additional coordinations will be made to account for changes at our facility that may affect the community emergency response plan.
Coordinations will include Valley Ags emergency response plan, updated emergency contact information, and any other information necessary for developing and implementing the local emergency response plan.
Coordination activities will be appropriately documented. The coordination records will include the names

of individuals involved and their contact information (phone number, email address, and organizational affiliations), dates of coordination activities, and nature of coordination activities.
The disclosure of information classified or restricted by the Department of Defense or other Federal agencies or contractors of such agencies is controlled by applicable laws, regulations, or executive orders concerning the release of that classified or restricted information.
1.5.2 Emergency Response Notification Exercises
At least once per calendar year, Valley Ag will conduct an exercise of the facilitys emergency response notifications mechanism. The facility will record each notification exercise utilizing PSMWriter.
Alternatively, the facility may meet the notification requirements through other exercises conducted to meet other Federal, state or local requirements, provided that the necessary notification is performed. Additionally, if a notification is made in response to an accidental release, this would also satisfy the notification requirement.
1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Valley Ag has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker, public, and environmental safety. Nevertheless, Valley Ag continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.
By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP Program. This has improved Valley Ags ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP related events so that Valley Ags management team can ensure that the RMP Program is being implemented.
Valley Ag has implemented all aspects of the RMP Program. When a RMP Program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item

has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.
In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Valley Ag has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP Program implementation.
Valley Ag considers the RMP Program a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Valley Ag employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP Program Valley Ag will continue to maintain overall plant worker, public, and environmental safety.
